chapter.title: Overall editing policy
chapter.para: This section still needs to be written. (And we could probably do with actually developing some real policy first..). Suggestions include: what we do about optimization, scripts, patches (where we put them; probably in the blfs-patches area of shadowfax) etc. etc. Contributions welcome; especially from (but not limited to) active editors.

listitem.para: acronym -- a word formed from the initial letter or letters of each of the successive parts or major parts of a compound term.

filename -- a filename, a fully qualified file name, a directory (use class="directory"), a library file (use class="libraryfile") or an extension (do not use class="extension" as it was added in DocBook XML DTD V4.2). Extensions should be written in all caps as many are also acronyms. Do not encapsulate an acronym tag with a filename tag, use either/or based on the usage.
These classes should not be used until the XML header is updated to V4.2 -- devicefile, headerfile, partition and symlink. They do, however, describe other files that should be tagged.
envar -- an environmental variable, can be common or temporary.
command -- any string that will execute when entered at the prompt (not just bash prompts).

userinput -- usually encapsulates "command" when it is expected that the user is required to input the command to proceed. "command"s may terminate within userinput to continue showing items that must be typed in, but are not commands. It is also used when command options are written without the command, as use <userinput>-q</userinput> for quiet operation. A preferable alternative may be to use the <option> tag.
application -- The proper name of the package.

screen -- This creates a 'verbatim' environment that allows spacing the be controlled. Mainly used as it simulates a console. It should not be encapsulated by <para> unless unscreened text is present.

replaceable -- used with screen to encapsulate text that is not to be typed as seen or copy and pasted. The text should also be encapsulated in brackets '[]' for text browser users. It should also be used outside of the 'screen' where your instructions are for what is to replace it.
prompt -- usually used within <screen> to mimic a prompt that should be seen by the user on his/her screen.

emphasis role="strong" -- used when an assumption is made in the instructions that may not always be true, i.e. your network connection is on <emphasis role=strong>eth0<emphasis>. Especially prior to giving script instructions using that assumption.
parameter -- used primarily in the command explanations section for items that are not commands.
